title: 111_hr2076
content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities while ensuring border security operations are carried out. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Defines terms like "Indian tribe," "Secretary," and "Secretary concerned." SEC. 4. BORDER PROTECTION STRATEGY. Border Protection Strategy to be developed by multiple Secretaries in consultation with various officials and submitted to Congress by September 30, 2009. Strategy to include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through different security measures. The Border Protection Strategy, to be developed by multiple Secretaries in consultation with various officials and submitted to Congress by September 30, 2009, will assess measures such as pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers, additional Border Patrol agents, natural barriers, and advanced technology for operational control. The Border Protection Strategy will include the fielding of advanced remote sensing technology, regional variations in border security methodologies, and enhanced cooperation with intelligence and security agencies. The Border Protection Strategy includes advanced remote sensing technology, regional variations in border security, cooperation with intelligence agencies, and removal of obstructive vegetation. Cost analysis is also included. The cost analysis of security measures includes land acquisition, construction, maintenance, contractor, management, and overhead costs, as well as impacts on wildlife, habitat, and hydrology. The curr_chunk discusses the impacts on wildlife habitats, migration corridors, and hydrology along the border, including the costs of mitigating these adverse effects. The curr_chunk discusses the impacts on wildlife habitats, migration corridors, and hydrology along the border, including the costs of mitigating these adverse effects, as well as the impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life on residents in the vicinity of the border. It also includes a comprehensive compilation of fiscal investments in acquiring or managing Federal, tribal lands. The curr_chunk focuses on the fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands and waters near the US borders for conservation purposes, including wildlife migration corridors in various national systems and under different jurisdictions. The curr_chunk lists various types of land under different jurisdictions, including National Forest System land, Bureau of Land Management land, United States Fish and Wildlife Service land, Department of the Interior or Agriculture land, Department of Defense land, Department of Commerce land, tribal lands, State and private lands, and lands within Mexico and Canada. The curr_chunk discusses recommendations for strategic border security management based on comparative security, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. Additionally, it mentions required training for Customs and Border Protection agents on natural resource protection. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary concerned, shall provide natural resource protection training for Customs and Border Protection agents or other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure and cultural resource training for those overseeing tribal lands. The Secretary, in cooperation with relevant tribal governments, provides training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure. Training focuses on achieving border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Amendment to improve operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, following a border protection strategy. Priority should be given to using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact border enforcement techniques. Consultation with other relevant departments is also mandated. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consult with various entities to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, and safety near proposed border enforcement actions. This consultation does not create or negate any rights of action for affected parties. The Secretary of Homeland Security is not required to install specific border security measures if deemed ineffective. This does not affect eminent domain laws or waive any other applicable laws. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to decide not to use barriers, roads, lighting, cameras, or sensors along the international border if they are not the most effective means of achieving operational control or if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 90 days after submitting the border protection strategy to Congress before starting any construction of fencing, barriers, roads, lighting, cameras, sensors, or other infrastructure along the US international land border. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, must develop a monitoring and mitigation plan for the ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan should address preserving wildlife habitats and migration corridors. The plan for monitoring and mitigating ecological impacts of border security infrastructure includes preserving wildlife migration corridors, key habitats, controlling invasive species, maintaining hydrological functionality, and incorporating adaptive management. The mitigation plan for border security infrastructure includes preserving wildlife migration corridors, key habitats, controlling invasive species, maintaining hydrological functionality, and protecting cultural and historical resources. The Secretary has the authority to carry out the plan on various lands regardless of ownership or responsibility. The Secretary of Homeland Security may transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on lands regardless of ownership or responsibility. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. Transferred funds are exempt from reprogramming requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security can use funds for developing and implementing a mitigation plan, accepting donations for this purpose, and transferring funds to other Federal agencies for expenditure. The funds transferred are exempt from reprogramming requirements.
